none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from C. P. Estill, October 20, 1881
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from C. P. Estill, October 20, 1881
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 10 Louis L. McInnis Papers

en: C. P. Estill writes to Louis L. McInnis at College Station, Texas on October 20, 1881, returning a book from the college library (Hume's History of England, Vol. I) that he discovered among his own possessions. The letter contains casual inquiries about college operations, including questions about curriculum adoption and personnel changes at the institution, while Estill reports on his own successful transition to teaching at a school in Huntsville, Texas.

body.value:
[Header]

Huntsville, Texas
Oct. 20th, 1881

Prof. L. L. McInnis
College Station,
Dear Sir,

I sent you by to-day's
mail, a Book belonging to the College Library,
discovered among my own a few days since.
Hume's Hist. of England, Vol. I. I do not think you
will find it charged on the Book. I suppose you
are still Librarian, & if you are not, please re-
turn it to its proper place.

I hope everything is going on harmonious-
ly, & lovingly – I was glad to hear that your numbers
were so encouraging – It was much better than
I expected, at the opening – I hope the President
does not feel overwhelmed with the sudden in
flux – How is my friend Gartner, & the "Optional
Department"? I hope he has nothing to annoy him
such as we both had last year –

I suppose you are enjoying yourself along
with Van Winkle in my old mansion –

We have a large school here – and things
are going very harmoniously so far, and

**Transcription Process - Expert Review** Alright, let's break this down. As a seasoned professional, I've approached this transcription with a methodical process. First, I analyzed the request, defining the transcriptionist role and understanding the task: transcribing an image, maintaining top-to-bottom reading order, high accuracy, and interpreting the handwriting. The guidelines are specific: maintain layout, use HTML tags (`a`, `b`, `br`, `i`, `img`, `p`, `small`, `span`, `sub`, `sup`), Markdown tables for data, and label structural elements. The final crucial constraint: ONLY the transcribed text. The image is a handwritten letter, late 19th-century cursive, and I've noted the location (Huntsville, Texas) and the date (Oct. 20th, 1881) at the top right, and the recipient is Prof. L. L. McInnis, College Station. The key here is the content: returning a library book ("Hume's Hist. of England, Vol. I"), questions about the college ("Gartner", "Optional Department"), and mentioning "Van Winkle" and an "old mansion". I'm also looking for references to the college situation. I'm transcribing section by section. The header, with the date and location, will be transcribed as `

Huntsville, Texas
Oct. 20th, 1881

`. I'm using `` for the "th" because the guidelines permit it and not ``. Next, the salutation `

Prof. L. L. McInnis
College Station,
Dear Sir,

`. The first body paragraph: `

I sent you by to-day's
mail, a Book belonging to the College Library,
discovered among my own a few days since.
Hume's Hist. of England, Vol. I. I do not think you
will find it charged on the Book. I suppose you
are still Librarian, & if you are not, please re-
turn it to its proper place.

`. "Hist." is an abbreviation and "&" is "and,". I'm noting the hyphenation "re-turn." Paragraph 2: `

I hope everything is going on harmonious-
ly, & lovingly – I was glad to hear that your numbers
were so encouraging – It was much better than
I expected, at the opening – I hope the President
does not feel overwhelmed with the sudden in
flux – How is my friend Gartner, & the "Optional
Department"? I hope he has nothing to annoy him
such as we both had last year –

`. I'm careful with the strikethrough at the start of the line and omitting it to stick to the allowed tags. "Gartner" and "Optional Department" (quoted) are crucial. "harmonious-" breaks across the line. Next, Paragraph 3: `

I suppose you are enjoying yourself along
with Van Winkle in my old mansion –

`. I'm keeping "Van Winkle" and "old mansion" as they appear. Finally, the partial fourth paragraph: `

We have a large school here – and things
are going very harmoniously so far, and

`. I've reviewed this meticulously: line breaks, capitalization (I'm using proper nouns from the original), punctuation (dashes are common), and I'm double-checking those tricky words: "McInnis", "Hume's Hist.", "since", "harmonious-ly", and "Gartner", and "Optional Department", "Van Winkle", and "mansion". Each of these is checked for clarity. I've double-checked the final formatting. I must wrap the sections in HTML and format the "th" properly. I'm using `

` for paragraphs and `
` for line breaks. Because the guidelines say "Label structural elements like [Header]... and wrap sections in HTML Markup Property values", I'm interpreting this as: the date and place are the header. The rest is the body. The date is a P tag. After more re-reading, it is better to provide the sections (Header and Body) in their proper HTML format. The labels help structure the understanding. One final check on "Optional Department"? The quote looks after the Department? Context is everything. I am now generating the output, making sure to stick to the constraint: ONLY the transcribed text. Here is the final structure, ready for delivery: ```html [Header]

I apprehend nothing else – My Colleagues are
all very pleasant and the work very agreea-
ble so far – Was Craig elected to the Missis
sippi Professorship? I have never seen any-
thing in the Religious papers in regard to it.
    Have the Beads- & Georgeson adopted the
Governor's Book, as a text-Book in Agricultu
ral matters? If they do not, why not? I think
of suggesting its adoption here as a text on
the Physical Geography of Texas – Don't you
think it would be a good move for me, to
say nothing of what it might be for the Nor-
mal Institute? But, excuse all this –
    I shall be glad to hear from you, when you
feel like writing – Mrs Estill begs to be remem-
bered to you – Very Sincerely, Your Friend

[Signature]
C. P. Estill.

P. S _ Have just received a note from "Van Winkle"
which informs me of the terrible march George-
son has stolen upon you – I would not stand
it, McInnis, I would fight – Get a corporal's
guard & run him out – It is too bad –

**Initial Assessment and Transcription Plan** Alright, let's break this down. My task is to transcribe a handwritten document image. The instructions are clear: read top-to-bottom, preserve everything—spelling, punctuation, capitalization—and use specific tags for formatting. I have to flag uncertainty with `[?]` and unreadable text with `[illegible]`. The primary focus is accuracy and strict adherence to the visual form, though context is key when there are ambiguous elements. It's a letter, likely from the 19th century, with cursive script. The content seems to be personal correspondence, likely academic or institutional matters given the mentions of "Professorship," "Governor's Book," and "Normal Institute." I'll need to carefully verify names like "Craig," "Beads & Georgeson," "Estill," "Van Winkle," and "McInnis." **Detailed Line-by-Line Transcription and Analysis** The process here is to read the document line by line and start thinking about the form that the rendered text will take. I'm taking the words as they appear, line by line. * *Line 1*: "I apprehend nothing else – My Colleagues are" * *Line 2*: "all very pleasant and the work very agreea-" * *Line 3*: "ble so far – Was Craig elected to the Missis" * *Line 4*: "sippi Professorship? I have never seen any-" * *Line 5*: "thing in the Religious papers in regard to it." * *Line 6*: "Have the [Beads?] & Georgeson adopted the" At this point, I've had to pause on the sixth line. The word "[Beads?]" has become a point of careful consideration. The handwriting is not completely clear, and "Beads" could be interpreted in several ways. The word is possibly "Heads", "Board", "Peards", "Reads", or even a specific name, but after scrutinizing the letters, especially how the "B" is formed in "Book" in line seven, it looks most like "Beads". I considered "Board" because that would fit the "adopted the Governor's Book" context better, but I've elected to just transcribe what I *see*. It is important to avoid guessing. I'm going to transcribe the word as "Beads". * *Line 7*: "Governor's Book, as a text-Book in Agricultu" * *Line 8*: "ral matters? If they do not, why not? I think" * *Line 9*: "of suggesting its adoption here as a text on" * *Line 10*: "the Physical Geography of Texas – Don't you" The words "Physical Geography" are struck through with a single wavy line. Given the instructions, I'll transcribe the words, even though they have been crossed out, as there is no way to include a strikethrough in my transcription. * *Line 11*: "think it would be a good move for me (to" The text "to" is at the end of the line, which could make it look like "me, to". * *Line 12*: "say nothing of what it might be for the Nor-" * *Line 13*: "mal Institute? But, excuse all this –" * *Line 14*: "I shall be glad to hear from you, when you" * *Line 15*: "feel like writing – Mrs Estill begs to be remem-" * *Line 16*: "bered to you – Very Sincerely Your Friend" **Signature and Postscript** *Signature*: "C. P. Estill." It's likely this is C.P. Estill of Sam Houston Normal Institute. *Postscript:* * *Line 1*: "P.
